docs.abstract: A second-quarter G.D.P. estimate is issued, and there will be a hearing on tariffs on Chinese goods.
docs.snippet: A second-quarter G.D.P. estimate is issued, and there will be a hearing on tariffs on Chinese goods.
docs.lead_paragraph: The tumult has continued for the American tech giants, but this week they get to focus on their main strength: making money. Google's parent company, Alphabet, announces its earnings on Monday after the closing bell. Then Facebook reports on Wednesday, Amazon on Thursday and Twitter on Friday. Alphabet's earnings call comes less than a week after European regulators fined the company $5.1 billion for abusing its dominance in the smartphone industry, while Facebook's chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, may have to handle questions about his company's confusing policies on hate speech and misinformation.

headline.main: Tech and Auto Earning Reports, and an E.U. Official Visits Trump
headline.print_headline: Silicon Valley and Detroit Set to Release Numbers

docs.abstract: A new report is drawing scrutiny to Foxconn’s employment practices again.
docs.snippet: A new report is drawing scrutiny to Foxconn’s employment practices again.
docs.lead_paragraph: Foxconn’s employment practices are drawing scrutiny again.

headline.main: Foxconn Is Under Scrutiny for Worker Conditions. It’s Not the First Time.

docs.abstract: Smart home devices will tell you the weather and answer trivia questions, sure, but they can do so much more. Try these tips to streamline your day, relax a little or just have some fun.
docs.snippet: Smart home devices will tell you the weather and answer trivia questions, sure, but they can do so much more. Try these tips to streamline your day, relax a little or just have some fun.
docs.lead_paragraph: If you’re an Amazon Echo or Google Home owner, you may only ask your device for the weather or to play music. That’s O.K., but these devices can do so much more — and they can offer more than a few useful tricks to make you feel as if you’re living in the future.

headline.main: The Most Fun (and Useful) Things You Can Do With an Amazon Echo or Google Home

docs.abstract: Tuesday Weld in “Pretty Poison” and Peggy Cummins in “Gun Crazy” are fresh-faced, trigger-happy young women in two films that attained cult status.
docs.snippet: Tuesday Weld in “Pretty Poison” and Peggy Cummins in “Gun Crazy” are fresh-faced, trigger-happy young women in two films that attained cult status.
docs.lead_paragraph: “Pretty Poison,” starring Anthony Perkins and Tuesday Weld, was hardly the greatest Hollywood movie of 1968. As a film about delusional young folk run murderously wild, and the subject of critics’ debates, it was however one of that turbulent year’s quintessential stories.

headline.main: In ‘Pretty Poison’ and ‘Gun Crazy,’ Femmes Fatales With Deadly Firepower

docs.abstract: The new anthology from the creator of “Mad Men” has moments of wonder amid sluggish storytelling.
docs.snippet: The new anthology from the creator of “Mad Men” has moments of wonder amid sluggish storytelling.
docs.lead_paragraph: As the creator of “Mad Men,” Matthew Weiner had a thing about spoilers. Each season arrived with a list of no-nos for critics, such as the number of floors in the advertising office where it was set. When he announced a series for Amazon Prime, I joked that maybe he’d make it a spoiler to say what the new show was about.

headline.main: Review: ‘The Romanoffs’ Is Elegant but Frustrating
headline.print_headline: All in the Family: Eclectic, but Frustrating

docs.abstract: Amazon and other tech giants have made devices connected to the internet increasingly prevalent. Now is the time to be freaking out about the dangers.
docs.snippet: Amazon and other tech giants have made devices connected to the internet increasingly prevalent. Now is the time to be freaking out about the dangers.
docs.lead_paragraph: More than 40 years ago, Bill Gates and Paul Allen founded Microsoft with a vision for putting a personal computer on every desk.

headline.main: A Future Where Everything Becomes a Computer Is as Creepy as You Feared

docs.abstract: The show’s costume designer explains the genesis of the most influential looks from Amazon’s new series.
docs.snippet: The show’s costume designer explains the genesis of the most influential looks from Amazon’s new series.
docs.lead_paragraph: Traveling in a horse-drawn buggy, a group of schoolgirls dressed in white pass through a small Australian town and pull off their gloves, their expressions giddy and relieved. They are headed to a picnic — and a tragedy — in the Australian countryside, and their headmistress, Mrs. Appleyard, had instructed them to wear their gloves until they escape the townspeople’s watchful glares.

headline.main: Costume Secrets From ‘Picnic at Hanging Rock’
headline.print_headline: Decoding ‘Picnic at Hanging Rock,’ Fold by Fold

docs.abstract: If you are getting ready to upgrade your e-reader or tablet and want to take your existing e-book library along, consider your options.
docs.snippet: If you are getting ready to upgrade your e-reader or tablet and want to take your existing e-book library along, consider your options.
docs.lead_paragraph: Q. Is it possible to read Nook books on a Kindle? Is there an e-reader that handles books from multiple e-bookstores?

headline.main: Moving Your E-Book Collection to One Device

docs.abstract: For a minimum investment of $10,000, people in the United States will be able to open and manage their own start-ups to deliver Amazon packages.
docs.snippet: For a minimum investment of $10,000, people in the United States will be able to open and manage their own start-ups to deliver Amazon packages.
docs.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Amazon has more than 100 warehouses. It has a fleet of trucks, and even its own airplanes. Now, in another effort to help get its millions of packages to shoppers faster, it wants to build an army of delivery people, too.

headline.main: Amazon Has a Business Proposition for You: Deliver Its Packages
headline.print_headline: Amazon Plans to Push Start-Ups To Help Deliver Its Own Packages

docs.abstract: We decided to test how easy it soon might be for people in Europe to access their personal data compared with users in the United States.
docs.snippet: We decided to test how easy it soon might be for people in Europe to access their personal data compared with users in the United States.
docs.lead_paragraph: We decided to test how easy it soon might be for people in Europe to access their personal data compared with users in the United States.

headline.main: U.K. vs. U.S.: How Much of Your Personal Data Can You Get?

byline.original: By Natasha Singer and Prashant S. Rao
